ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to model a robot, how to control that model

I learned a lot about different schemes of modeling and controlling robots. I also gained additional experience in python and gained a more intuitive understanding of certain mathematical concepts such as gradient descent.
Through this course, I learned how to derive a dynamics model for a robot and different direct and indirect control methods.

This course provides an overview of the methods to model and control robots in a computer simulation, a skill which is needed in order to program complex robotic systems. It's extremely math-heavy, going into the details of control theory.

The first half of the class was modeling (Euler-Lagrange equations, Lie groups), and the second half was control (LQR, iLQR, direct transcription, MPC). From the problem sets, I now have working code for a number of these things. However, I'm not sure I'd say I actually understand it well, because most of the code was either given to us or just a very simple fill-in-the-blank.
I learned the mathematical basis of physics modeling for robots and several robot control strategies

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: homeworks were very conducive to learning
Weakness: lectures were sometimes very overwhelming in terms of derivations

Strengths: Pretty well laid out, and pretty lenient grade-wise. Weaknesses: Course is very focused in abstract math and this sometimes makes it hard for students to understand. It also feels somewhat mainly tailored to graduate students instead of the undergraduates in the class.

This course covers a massive amount of content that is foundational to modern robotics in a clear and effective manner. Despite moving quickly, the workload remained reasonable save for two or three points in the semester.

We relied upon Professor Abraham's notes, as there was no textbook for the course. When I found his notes confusing, there were not many other places to turn for help. More office hours would have been helpful. Since each of the assignments were a coding problem, most time at office hours was spent troubleshooting code rather than increasing my understanding of the subject.

Strengths: The topics were interesting, the course notes were solid, and I liked the midterm and final projects.
Weaknesses: I thought this class tried to cover too much content, and I was left not deeply understanding much of it. The lectures were very math-heavy. I was able to follow the individual steps, but I would get lost in the weeds and lose track of the big picture, and I'm not sure I'd be able to apply much of the math. When we had to apply things on the problem sets, there was so much guidance in the comments that I could complete the assignments without actually understanding the content. From talking to other students, I know many people had similar experiences with the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, the course taught very realistic applications

I would recommend this to any other student interested in robotics or the math behind engineering. It was definitely an interesting course and the projects we made over the course of the semester felt useful and productive.

I would absolutely recommend this course to any student who wants to learn about the principles of robotics. You will gain a strong background in modeling and simulation through this class, and if you continue to study robotics, you will reference the lecture notes from this class for years to come. However, only take this course if you have solid experience in Python and a background in (or willingness to try out) abstract math.
If you're interested in robotics, just know that this course is very theory-based and will not translate to real-world applications until you get really good at understanding control theory.

On the one hand, this class covers topics that are useful for robotics, and you'll leave the class with a fair amount of working code. On the other hand, I don't feel that I left the class with a deep understanding of the material. We covered so much that we had to rush through it, so the lectures moved quickly through very complicated math, and the problem sets did a lot of the work for us. I think the class would have been better if we'd covered less but did it more thoroughly.
This course should not be taken as an introduction to robotics. There is a lot of information here and it comes at you fast so be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to this course.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in a career related to robotics, but be aware that it is very math heavy and moves very fast. The work is manageable, though, even if you don't understand all the math.
Highly recommend! This is a great crash course in robot modelling and control. If you're interested in these subjects, this course covers the must-know material.
